Deficiency Narrative: One triggered review document did not have the required information.
Correction Narrative: As per the Director of Emergency Shelter, to ensure compliance and improve documentation quality related to triggered reviews, they have met with case managers to discuss expectations for documenting supervision details. After receiving clarification during monitoring inspection, the operation have implement necessary adjustments promptly. The operation notes being committed to using the guidance received to strengthen their documentation processes and ensure that supervision plans accurately reflect each youths needs.

Deficiency Narrative: Three of five child service plans did not have the required information as to date provided and/or justification whether or not a copy was provided.
Correction Narrative: As per the Director of Emergency Shelter, management have met with case managers to reinforce the importance of obtaining signatures consistently. Together, they developed a streamlined process to ensure all DFPS-related documents are signed and properly filed. This improvement supports accountability and ensures youth and their supports are actively included in service planning.

Deficiency Narrative: Four of four Preliminary Service Plan documentation reviewed failed to the required information.
Correction Narrative: As per the Director of Emergency Shelter, to enhance the quality and completeness of preliminary service plans, lead youth care workers and direct care staff were engaged in a staff meeting focused on expectations at intake. All staff discussed how to use existing toolssuch as common applications and psychological assessmentsto gather essential information and create accurate, individualized preliminary service plans. This approach ensures that youth needs are addressed immediately and appropriately from the moment of admission.

Deficiency Narrative: Six Unauthorized Absences debriefings were not completed and/or documented.
Correction Narrative: As per the Director of Emergency Shelter, the operation is committed to improving their practices to ensure consistent, high-quality care and accountability. They recognize how crucial it is to complete incident debriefs with youth upon their return from an unauthorized absence and to maintain uniformity in how staff document and conduct these conversations. Since reinforcing these expectations, staff have been completing debrief forms in full, and leadership has reviewed each debrief within 24 hours of the incident. To sustain this progress, the operation will continue emphasizing timely and accurate debriefing during onboarding and ongoing training. These efforts reflect the operation's dedication to providing consistent, thoughtful follow-up after critical events.

Deficiency Narrative: Staff failed to arrange and confirm transportation back to the operation for a child in care who called for assistance after traveling 50 miles away on their bicycle.
Correction Narrative: An email was received September 26, 2025 stating: moving forward, we ask that all organizations coordinate directly to avoid relying on youth to relay information. LifeWorks remains committed to supporting youth through structured activities and ensuring transportation is provided when appropriate.

Deficiency Narrative: During the Walkthrough of bedroom #9, a whole in the wall was present. In another room, the vent is partially coming from ceiling.
A child's unauthorized absence was not recorded on the Annual Summary Log.
Correction Narrative: The operation stated they had a glitch in the syncing of the systems but that all the unauthorized absences were logged appropriately.

Deficiency Narrative: During the inspection of girls bathroom, the hot water handle on the 1st sink to the left did not turn on water. There is a potential leak  under the sink area as there was water on the floor under sink extending to the first two toilets in girl's bathroom.
Correction Narrative: On 1/27/25, the Director of the operation reported that they spoke with the licensing representative on this investigation on 1/16/25 regarding the deficiency related to the plumbing issues in one of two bathrooms. It was reported the problem was first reported to them on Friday, 1/10/25 and their maintenance team responded immediately and temporarily addressed the issue, but parts had to be ordered for a permanent fix. Once the parts arrived, maintenance completed the repairs later that same day, after the licensing rep on the inv. had left the facility. The Director reported they contacted that rep to inform them that the issue had been resolved, and that rep requested the maintenance ticket. The ticket was sent to that rep at 2:17 pm on 1/16/25. The operation is requesting an admin review for this deficiency.

Deficiency Narrative: In reviewing the Service Plans for both children a general statement was given and not specific details for each child.
Correction Narrative: In response to these deficiencies, the Director reported they have organized an all-staff training to review supervision expectations both onsite and offsite. Additionally, they updated and attached their emergency shelter manual policies/procedures, specifically section 5, to reflect the expectations for youth supervision. The Director reported they have also met with their case managers (CMs) to discuss and clarify the licensing expectations for service plans. They have since made significant progress in ensuring their service plans meet the required standards. The Director reported they will continue to support the CMs through follow-up emails, case staffing, and regular supervisions to review each new youth and their service plans. The Director reported they are hopeful that the follow-ups and training initiatives will continue to support their efforts in reaching the standards in providing the highest quality care for the youth in their program.

Deficiency Narrative: Children are being allowed to leave the facility and are unaware of where the children are at or are going. Children are remaining gone for hours at a time without a check in with staff or staff checking on them.
Correction Narrative: In response to these deficiencies, the Director reported they have organized an all-staff training to review supervision expectations both onsite and offsite. Additionally, they updated and attached their emergency shelter manual policies/procedures, specifically section 5, to reflect the expectations for youth supervision. The Director reported they have also met with their case managers (CMs) to discuss and clarify the licensing expectations for service plans. They have since made significant progress in ensuring their service plans meet the required standards. The Director reported they will continue to support the CMs through follow-up emails, case staffing, and regular supervisions to review each new youth and their service plans. The Director reported they are hopeful that the follow-ups and training initiatives will continue to support their efforts in reaching the standards in providing the highest quality care for the youth in their program.

Deficiency Narrative: Citation: The child did not return to the van at 9:45PM when planned with staff. This report was not made to the hotline until 1:34AM, roughly 3.5 hours after the incident occurred. With the child's sex trafficking history the incident should have been reported immediately.
Correction Narrative:
An email was received on 1.17.25 from the operation. The operation reported expectations and requirements are communicated with staff during weekly case staff meetings and via email regarding contacting licensing immediately following police contact when they have suspected human trafficking concerns. They also reported the requirement has been added to their policies in their shelter manual and they will continue to train all new staff of this policy moving forward. They additionally reported they are working to schedule an all-staff training to give clarity on reporting future incidents and timeframes.

On 1/21/25, the assigned licensing representative sent the operation an email asking them what date they have scheduled the all-staff training. It was requested they provide the date this is completed or will be completed and a copy of the staff signatures who attended the training be provided as well. The operation replied that a Supervisor and the Director are working on scheduling the all-staff meeting for late February (2025).

Deficiency Narrative: During the course of the investigation, it was reported that multiple residents have brought contraband and used contraband on campus.
Correction Narrative: The operation scheduled an installation date to update their security systems, prioritized training on proactive responses, and are in the process of organizing an all-staff training to review both current and new procedures. The operation is also discussing the idea of implementing an earlier curfew and updating policy on searches.

Deficiency Narrative: It was found that operation staff had suspicion of several residents shoplifting/stealing from different stores in the community and bringing a variety of contraband back onto to campus, to include alcohol/illegal substances and other items, for some time, however the operation failed to create safety plans for the children to address these concerns.
Correction Narrative: The operation scheduled an installation date to update their security systems, prioritized training on proactive responses, and are in the process of organizing an all-staff training to review both current and new procedures. The operation is also discussing the idea of implementing an earlier curfew and updating policy on searches.

Deficiency Narrative: It was found that during a search conducted by staff in a child's room at the operation on 11/5/24, two THC pens, a vape pen, one lighter, and four empty boxes of THC related products were discovered. Staff also found a razor, one pair of scissors, and Tylenol as well.
Correction Narrative:
On 12/2/24, the Director reported that they keep in constant contact with the children's case workers to discuss safety plans and placement options and notify them of every incident and concern that they may have.

On 12/4/24, the assigned licensing representative for this operation had a discussion by phone with the Administrator and the Director regarding this deficiency and the contraband concern that should addressed by the operation.

On 12/5/24, the Director reported they will be working with the Case Manager to discuss on-going service planning to address high-risk behaviors. The Director also reported that their room search plan is that staff will start to complete room searches at least twice a month. Day shift will complete room searches between the 1st-10th and evening shift will complete room searches between the 15th-30th of each month. These searches will be documented, and they will be updating their policy in their shelter manual to reflect this new change.

On 12/13/24, the Director created safety plans for children in care who the operation had concerns about regarding bringing either illegal substances, tobacco, and/or alcohol on campus. Children were searched on this day by a staff upon them coming back from off campus to ensure no contraband was being brought onto campus. During an inspection on 12/13/24, this licensing representative observed this being done with four different children who returned from the community, and they were cleared as no contraband was found on their person.

Deficiency Narrative: During the walkthrough of the operation an uncovered bowl of cheese was observed in a refrigerator. [
A child was dropped off at an unknown person's home by staff.
Correction Narrative: The Administrator stated that they have put several new processes in place regarding the unauthorized absences of children at the operation and one process involves utilizing safety plans and working with the CPS caseworkers to ensure that the child's high risk behaviors are documented and there are protocols put in place for those high risk behaviors. The Administrator sent an email to the assigned licensing representative wanting to follow up and ask one question in regard to the deficiency. The Administrator states in the deficiency it references dropping off children at various locations and the recommendation being for them to keep record of who they drop children off with. The Administrator reported for this incident regarding an unauthorized leave (UL) for a child, the UL documentation notes that the child left the operation on their own accord and was not dropped off at an unknown location by staff. The Administrator wanted to check to see if the incident was accurately reported and that the UL documentation shared was properly understood. Admin review was requested.

Deficiency Narrative: During the inspection it was found that the background check for the operation's current CEO as of July 1, 2024, has been inactive and their former CEO's background check was also inactive prior to 7/1/24.
Correction Narrative: On 9/11/24, the operation reported by email that they have gotten in touch with their HR to ensure they get the proper background check (BGC) completed. The also sent an email to their CBCU representative (rep) to gain clarification regarding BGCs and CBCU informed them of the requirements. On 9/13/24 the operation sent an email reporting their current procedures include that all shelter staff, volunteers, and interns are subject to complete a background check in accordance with Minimum Standards/TAC. On 11/6/24, an in-person follow up was conducted to verify that the CEO's background check had been completed. This was cleared on 9/16/24 once it was run after the previous inspection on 9/10/24 and is in compliance.

Deficiency Narrative: During the inspection, it was found that two child files were missing another method of identifying the child.
Correction Narrative: The operation Division Director of Emergency and Transitional Housing sent an email on 9/20/24 to their assigned licensing representative, reporting that they emailed their entire facility team with notification of this minimum standard requirement and what the specific findings were during the monitoring. It was communicated that all children need to have a client ID included on the front of the child file and on the top of the Client Demographic Form, which is at the front of the child file. They reported they have established a plan to use the Client ID number as the standard identifying number that they can use, since all residents at the facility will have a unique Client ID that they can use to differentiate and identify each child. They have also held a specific meeting with their YCW Lead AM staff member who is the primary staff responsible for completing and reviewing all child files after intake. In this meeting they also updated their Intake Packet Cover Page as well as their Demographic Form to be more specific in requesting the Client ID. On the Intake Packet Cover Page, they reported they have listed the Client ID to be written underneath the child's name. On the Demographic Form, they have edited the document to request the Client ID to replace what used to be labeled Case #.

Deficiency Narrative: During the inspection, it was found there was documentation missing for the staff's qualifications.
Correction Narrative: The operation Division Director of Emergency and Transitional Housing sent an email on 9/20/24, reporting that the staff member who did not have their education verification has sent in verification of their High School Diploma. The operation Division Director also reported that they and the Administrator have spoken with their HR team about gathering documentation to verify the education status of all shelter staff upon hire. Their HR team is planning to do a self-audit to ensure that they have education verification for all current staff, or any required professional licensures, certifications or registrations, required for their position. The operation Division Director also attached the high school diploma for the staff file that was evaluated to be missing this for proof of verification of education.

Deficiency Narrative: During the inspection, it was found that the psychotropic medication training for one staff file was not led by a qualified health care professional.
Correction Narrative: On 9/20/24, the Division Director reported they have sent an email to their entire shelter team that they are going to review their onboarding process as it relates to training the administration of psychotropic medication. The Division Director reported their Chief Operations Officer has also begun reaching out to health-care professionals in the community to provide instructor-led training for when they have new hires. They also reported theyve communicated with their HR team that they are required to have instructor-led training on administering psychotropic medication from a health-care professional or pharmacist. They reported they will track and document this training as new employees onboard.

Deficiency Narrative: The triggered reviews for 3 children did not have details about the unauthorized absences which triggered the review and did not explain prior debriefings with the child.
Correction Narrative: An email was received by the operation on 8.27.24. It was explained a meeting was held with the Case Manager and Youth Care Worker Supervisors to discuss the deficiency and review the standard. Supervisor will make debriefings electronically available via Teams for easy retrieval.

Deficiency Narrative: On 6/14/24, during the walkthrough, a nail clipper (considered as contraband), was in a child's room. This has been cited two other times in less than 3 months.
The unauthorized absence log documented the staff who reported the incident to the hotline instead of the staff responsible for the child at the time of the incident.
Correction Narrative: An email was received from the operation on 6.13.24. It was explained the Unauthorized Absence Log was revised and backdated to 6/1/2024 to include the staff responsible for the child at the time of the incident instead of what was previously recorded. Emergency Shelter Supervisors reviewed the changes with their direct reports. The Director of the Emergency Shelter demonstrated proper use of the log during our team meeting on Tuesday, June 4th and a virtual staff check-in meeting was held on 6/13/2024 to answer questions or provide coaching.

Deficiency Narrative: The triggered review did not have details about the previous 4 unauthorized absences and did not explain prior debriefings with the child.
Correction Narrative: An email was received from the operation on 6.13.24. The Emergency Shelter Director reviewed the deficiency with Case Manager responsible for completing all client Triggered Reviews. Scheduled meetings will occur moving forward to thoroughly review and ensure Triggered Reviews include prior briefing information, the causes and resolution of unauthorized absences, and trends observed. Requirements shared by CCR Representative provided support. The operation will refer to the standard for continued clarity.

Deficiency Narrative: During the follow up inspection, a broken cylindrical glass tube was observed by licensing on the floor of a child's room that had not been discarded. Staff had not been aware of this. This was corrected at inspection.
Through interviews and documentation, it was determined that a primary caregiver could not physically intervene and stop in altercation.
Correction Narrative: On 4/23/24, the assigned licensing rep conducted an unannounced inspection and there were no concerns noted relating to this standard. It was reported by children and staff that staff intervene and react properly when incidents occur.

Deficiency Narrative: Through documentation and interviews it was determined that staff was aware that residents liked to collect items from the community and bring them back into the operation. Items considered contraband were found in a resident's room.
A child in care left the operation and a report was made almost 3 hours after required timeframes.
Correction Narrative: The operation has spoken with staff and shift supervisors in regard to the needs of reporting timely.  This was completed over 2 days.

Deficiency Narrative: After reviewing 1 child file, it was found that the recreation section in the service plan was missing.
Correction Narrative:
Following the unannounced visit on 9/20/23, Lifeworks Shelter Director met with Shelter Case Manager to discuss the deficiencies received. The Director and Division Director have reviewed the following deficiency and addressed it in the following way:

The operation reported all LifeWorks shelter clients follow a daily schedule and programming designed to respond to their needs and individual goals. The facility's recreational activities and outings are designed to offer youth activities that focus on Educational, Self-Care, Physical/Active, Arts and Crafts, Entertainment, and Outdoor. Youth are also encouraged to share ideas and suggestions they have for recreation by completing an Activity Request Form. LifeWorks Shelter Director met with the programs Case Manager (CM) to discuss the expectation of notating all plans for social, extracurricular, recreation, and leisure activities in each childs service plan. To ensure compliance with this standard, all service plans will be reviewed and audited for completion by the Director and CM prior to signing. Additionally, to ensure that the recreation section is not missed or left empty, the CM will reference planned activities scheduled for the week/month and notate any and all that the child shows interest in participating in. If none are identified, the CM will provide the child with the Activity Request Form that can be completed together and documented in their service plan.

Deficiency Narrative: It was found that there was no communication log for the child/victim for after this child left the facility on 7/2/23 at 10:00 pm. There was no update on whether the child returned to the facility.
Correction Narrative: On 9/8/23, the operation reported LifeWorks Emergency Shelter staff are instructed to update all documentation when youth return to the operation including their condition upon return, debrief of the incident and any restrictions applied moving forward. Staff also notify managing conservators of the youths return and cancel APD reports as needed. As a result of the deficiency, Shelter Director met with Youth Care Worker Supervisors to include a communication note section to the Unauthorized Leave (UL) form in order to provide updates of the youths runaway status including attempts made to contact youth, youth contacting the shelter while on runaway status, and/or any notes relating to the youths runaway status. An updated UL template form was provided with follow up response.

Deficiency Narrative: It was found that on 6/24/23, the operation received a screenshot of an inappropriate text message sexual in nature sent to them by a minor resident at the facility that had received the message from a young adult resident there, however the operation didn't see the screenshot until 6/30/23 and then called this into the A/N hotline upon discovery. It is unknown if the text message was sent to the minor resident on or off campus.
Correction Narrative:
On 9/8/23, the operation reported all LifeWorks shelter clients are provided with the Emergency Shelter number at intake and again when completing orientation. The number is also posted in the milieu for quick access. Clients are also encouraged to call anytime (24/7) while in the community, if they encounter any danger and/or feel unsafe. The operation reported if a client does not have a phone or an active phone plan, LifeWorks can provide one and unfortunately, this client alerted a staff of the inappropriate texts while this staff was out of the office and
the messages were not seen until days later. To avoid incidents such as these in the future, LifeWorks Shelter Director will monitor work phones assigned to Emergency Shelter Case Managers when they are out of the office or on leave. Case Managers will notify all shelter clients when they are unavailable and/or out of the office. Case Managers will also encourage clients to speak with Emergency Shelter staff regarding any concerns, requests, and/or inquiries during their absence.

Deficiency Narrative: After reviewing documentation, it was determined that the operation reported to the hotline 2 days after the UA occurred.
Correction Narrative: An email was received from the operation. Upon receiving the conclusion letter for investigation #3006878, Lifeworks Shelter Director met with Youth Care Worker shift supervisors to address the deficiency received. It was discovered that the oversight was a result of the youths constant in/out presence at the shelter and runaway status. We determined that our notification practices needed to be reinforced and sent an email to the entire team with instructions and reporting expectations. To ensure that all serious incident reports are reported in a timely manner (no later than 6 hours after determining an unauthorized absence of a child), we relabeled our filing system to create a more streamlined process of notification. This was followed up by a team meeting on 7/6/2023 and provided additional support and coaching to staff.

Deficiency Narrative: During this inspection, it was found that one bedroom (#7) had clutter and lot of other belongings thrown around the room to which could pose a safety hazard. There was also a ceiling fixture in bedroom #2 that needed repair and a towel rack in the bathroom of bedroom #5 that also needed repair.
Correction Narrative: The operation reported that the Lifeworks Shelter Director met with Youth Care Worker shift supervisors to address the clutter in room #7. With the assistance of staff, child was able to clean and organized their room/bathroom (see photos). Theyve established incentives in the past for child(ren) productivity. However, they have started implementing monetary incentives upon a child cleaning their room with the hopes that they feel motivated to keep their space tidy. Youth Care Workers working the evening shift will block out time to assist child(ren) with deep cleans and document when they are completed. Case Manager and Director will meet with the child(ren) and issue action plans if bedrooms are not in compliance with the minimum standards. Lastly, maintenance requests were submitted and completed for the ceiling fixture in room #2 and the towel rack in the bathroom (of bedroom #5). Photos provided. Additionally, all LifeWorks Emergency Shelter staff are expected to report and submit any maintenance requests should any furnishings or facilities need repair. During hourly room/perimeter checks, Youth Care Workers will ensure that common spaces are clean and safe. The evening staff will schedule time with children to assist with deep cleans in order to maintain a clean environment.

Deficiency Narrative: During the inspection, the TB test results, driver's license record, Affidavit for application of employment, and drug tests results were not available for review for two of two staff files.
Correction Narrative: Following the 9/28/22 visit, Lifeworks Shelter Director met with Human Resources Director to go over the requirements in relation to this standard. HR continues to complete and oversee the onboarding process for all LifeWorks staff and are responsible for storing paper copies of TB test results, drivers license records, Affidavit for application of employment, and drug test results at Lifeworks South location at 3700 S. 1st Street. These records are currently in the process of being uploaded electronically and will be shared with the Shelter Director via Microsoft Teams. HR Director confirmed that Shelter staff files can be prioritized so that information can be readily available in the future.

Deficiency Narrative: During the inspection, it was found that two children were not administered their prescription medication(s) on 9/24/22 and 9/25/22 and one of the two children also wasn't given their prescription medication on 9/27.
Correction Narrative: Following the 9/28/22 visit, Lifeworks Shelter Director met with Youth Care Worker supervisors to go over the requirements in relation to this standard. They identified that the best way to move forward would be to retrain current staff on their medication procedures and ensure that they are properly documenting when medications are/are not dispensed (including reason). The operation Youth Care Worker III has met with primary medication staff to address errors from dates listed above. A Medication and Documentation refresher training has been scheduled for 10/9/22, 10/11/22, and 10/29/22 from 10:00am  12:00pm.

Deficiency Narrative: A unauthorized absence of a child in care was reported 4 hours after the required timeframe to Licensing.
Correction Narrative: An email was received on 11.7.22 from the Shelter's Director. The Director explained she met with supervisors and staff to discuss the UA. It was mentioned there was initial confusion surrounding the child's discharge status and the staff responsible for initiating the UA did not do so. The staff responsible no longer works at the operation, effective 9.27.22. Communications were sent to staff to reiterate documentation procedures and reporting timelines.

Deficiency Narrative: After reviewing 5 out of 5 incident reports, it was observed that there was no documented resolution or follow up of the incident.
Correction Narrative:
An email was received from Yuri Cueto stating the following: Following the report received on 6/24/22, Lifeworks Shelter Director met with Case Manager, Kevin Lankford and Youth Care Worker IIIs to discuss the TA received. Case Managers are tasked to document updates, summary of conversations, and outcomes on all client IRs. To ensure that documentation is
readily available and consistently updated, Youth Care Workers will also include their notations and follow-up interactions with clients. Youth Care Workers already have conversations following incidents, complete safety plans, and document observations in shift notes to share with the rest of the team. Case Manager will continue to schedule follow-ups after a serious incident has occurred and should the client be unavailable, a shift supervisor (YCW III) will attempt to follow-up with said client in the evening, overnight, or weekend shift. Shelter Director will also ensure that a resolution is clearly stated on the incident report prior to signing and filing.

Deficiency Narrative: Through the course of the investigation, it was discovered that a child in care performed a restraint on a peer. Staff verbally tried to stop the restraint that started in a physical fight but did not physically try to stop the restraint that lasted approximately a minute.
Correction Narrative:
Operation sent the following compliance plan. "Shelter Director met with agency EBI certified 
instructors and Youth Care Worker IIIs to discuss the TA received. A scheduled refresher training 
for all shelter staff will take place on June 10th and 13th. This refresher will be mandatory and will cover the physical portion of our chosen EBI (Handle with Care). We will also incorporate scenarios including the one that occurred in order to provide staff will clear guidelines and expectations during client altercations. We will continue to request that staff communicate observations and interactions with clients in Shift Notes (completed on every shift) that inform Emergency Shelter staff of observed tension, incidents, and clients that are need of additional support and/or supervision"

Deficiency Narrative: The unauthorized absence of a youth in care at the operation was reported outside of the required timeframe to licensing.
Correction Narrative: The operation provided a document of a written corrective action for the staff member. The corrective action clarified the standards for reporting to law enforcement and licensing.

Deficiency Narrative: During the inspection, there were staff who were inactivated past the 7 day required timeframe of being terminated/resigned. There were 9 out of 13 staff that were inactivated past this timeframe and there were 2 staff that were reported to be terminated who had not been inactivated.
Correction Narrative: The operation Director met with the Human Resources Director to go over the requirements in relation to this standard. HR continues to oversee the background check process for all operation staff and is responsible for inactivating background checks. They were made aware of the need to inactivate background checks within 7 days of leaving the operation. Given their recent turnover, the HR Director confirmed that they would personally take this on and would set up weekly reminders to ensure that the operation is in compliance with the Minimum Standards. The HR Director also confirmed that they would be sure to emphasize how critical this is with their next HR Generalist and will also spot check periodically. The Shelter Director will also confirm deactivation with HR prior to the 7th day.

Deficiency Narrative: During the inspection, children's medication records count were observed to not match the number of actual tablets/pills left.
Correction Narrative: The Shelter Director held a team meeting to discuss the feedback received from licensing. It was determined that their medication sheets would include a medication count after the following distribution times: AM, NOON, PM, and BEDTIME. They will continue to do medication counts on the overnight as well. It was reported this change will allow them to accurately demonstrate the daily count of each prescribed medication within two-hours of dispensing said medication to the child and ensure that they're in compliance. The operation attached the updated medication sheet as well.

Deficiency Narrative: During the inspection, two staff records were requested, however licensing was unable to thoroughly evaluate these records as the personnel files were not immediately available.
Correction Narrative: The Shelter Director met with the Human Resources Director to go over the requirements in relation to this standard. In the future, employee files will be moved to an all-electronic format, but in the interim, it was determined that employee information gathered by HR would be forwarded to the Shelter Director so delays when inquiring staff files would no longer occur. The Senior Division Director and Senior Grants and Contracts Specialist will also have access should the Shelter Director be out of the office.

Deficiency Narrative: During the inspection, it was found that two of two personnel files reviewed were missing sections of this standard.
Correction Narrative: The operation designed a specific training model called "Needs of Children in Lifeworks Care Training", that covers all related topics in this section of the minimum standards. This training will be incorporated into all future pre-service training sessions.

Deficiency Narrative: After reviewing the list of terminated staff, it was found that 5 staff were inactivated after the 7 day required time frame for inactivation.
Correction Narrative:
The operation reported that on 11/16/20 the Director reached out to the operation's Human Resources Department (HR) to reiterate the requirements in relation to this standard. As HR oversees the background check process for the operation, they are the ones who inactivate background checks, so they were made aware of the need to inactivate background checks within 7 days of a staff leaving the operation. HR has since updated their procedures in the following way to ensure that they are in compliance with this standard moving forward: "HR have set this task up as a weekly task for the HR Team moving forward to say on top of this process and in compliance."

service plans: 748.1339(c) and 748.1349(a)(l) ensure child attends service plan meeting, signs and dates the plan, and receives a copy of it. The Director has met with operation Case Managers and has gone over the documentation that is required for service plans, including how to document if a youth declines to attend, sign, date, or take copy of the service plan. Staff will follow these protocols in the future.

timely gas pipe inspections: 748.3061(2). Lifeworks Head of Facilities, who organizes these inspections has stated will ensure these get done yearly to stay in compliance.

Ensuring all documents are in youth files within 30 days: 748.395(1). During Covid-19, Case Managers have been off site as much as possible in line with Lifeworks Covid-19 safety protocols. This has limited their access to printers and the youth files. The Director has asked them to access other printers and to ensure that documents get into youth files within the required timeframes.
